content:
The Rent Reform and Empowerment Act of 1995 may be cited as the "Rent Reform and Empowerment Act of 1995". It includes provisions regarding ceiling rents. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to specify criteria for determining rental amounts in public housing projects owned and operated by agencies. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to specify criteria for determining rental amounts in public housing projects owned and operated by agencies. Ceiling rents established by a public housing agency may be adjusted and take effect at the agency's discretion. Regulations must be issued before ceiling rents established under certain subclauses can take effect. The Secretary must issue regulations within 180 days of the Rent Reform and Empowerment Act of 1995 enactment. Before these regulations take effect, agencies must determine the reasonable rental value based on specific criteria for projects and comparable units. SEC. 3. EXCLUSIONS FROM ADJUSTED INCOME. Section 3(b)(5) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include documentation of family payments for health insurance and medical expenses for family members not receiving government healthcare assistance, limited to families in public housing. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include provisions for families residing in public housing, such as excluding 20 percent of earned income and allowing for earned income of formerly dependent children in the family. The Rent Reform and Empowerment Act of 1995 amended the United States Housing Act of 1937 to include provisions for redetermining rent and family composition when a child reaches 18 years old, with exclusions for earned income if the child is in high school or equivalent program. The Rent Reform and Empowerment Act of 1995 amended the United States Housing Act of 1937 to include provisions for redetermining rent and family composition when a child reaches 18 years old, with exclusions for earned income if the child is in high school or equivalent program. Additionally, in the case of 2-parent families with children residing in public housing, an amount not to exceed 10 percent of any earned income of the family may be excluded to prevent significant financial hardship. SEC. 4. EXCLUSION OF EARNED INCOME OF RESIDENTS WHO OBTAIN EMPLOYMENT FROM RENT DETERMINATIONS. Section 3(a) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow public housing agencies to exclude earned income from rent determination for families previously unemployed for 1 or more years. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to exclude earned income from rent determination for families previously unemployed for 1 or more years. The rent for a family member employed during a specific period should not increase by more than one-third of the difference between the current rent and the rent that would be paid without this provision. The rent increase should not exceed the amount determined under specific paragraphs. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME OF EARNINGS FROM JOB TRAINING AND SELF-SUFFICIENCY PROGRAMS. Section 3 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to exclude earnings and benefits from employment training programs from being considered as income for determining rent limitations for public housing residents. The United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to exclude earnings and benefits from employment training programs from being considered as income for determining rent limitations for public housing residents. Additionally, a paragraph in subsection (c)(3) is removed. SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY.

Residents of public housing under a specific program before this Act will continue to be governed by the same authority.

SEC. 7. PERFORMANCE FUNDING SYSTEM. SEC. 7 amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to include the calculation of reduced revenue from excluding income of public housing residents in the payment received by the public housing agency. The amendments made by this Act will take effect either when the regulations under section 9 are effective or after 120 days from the enactment of this Act. The Secretary will issue final regulations to implement these amendments within the same 120-day period, following the procedures for public comment.
